body.p: On reading the recent paper in this journal by Qian et al. [1], I have the following comments to make. I wondered why in Table 1 octane numbers for hydrogen and petroleum fuel are given when the work is concerned with a compression ignition engine. Surely, it is the cetane number which is relevant, and not the octane number. I note also that the octane number of hydrogen is given as 130. This can be compared with information in an article in one of this “family” of journals from 2004 [2]. This tabulates octane numbers of several fuels for SI engines as the mean of the research and motor values (respectively, Research Octane Number; RON and Motor Octane Number; MON). It explicitly states that such a mean does not apply to hydrogen and that the RON > 130. The RON and MON are so far apart for hydrogen that a mean of the two is not helpful. Use of a single value 130 in Ref. [1] is therefore, difficult to justify.

It is stated on page 1920 of Ref. [1] that LPG is one of the fuels “aspiring to replace petroleum fuels”. LPG is of course obtained either from crude oil or from natural gas condensate, so it is a petroleum fuel. And why does “natural gas” appear in this list of “aspirant” fuels?
